body:
It seems like [this](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/e7130723ba11f8a6e14db141f5239d132f8284d4/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/SeparateThreadTimeoutInvocation.java#L42) handling is not needed since it is catching the wrong type of exception and also because the `assertTimeoutPreemptively` handles internally the timeout. Also, I realized that there are some inconsistencies in the exceptions generated by the `SameThreadTimeoutInvocation#proceed` and the `assertTimeoutPreemptively`. The former [throws](https://github.com/gilbertojrequena/junit5/blob/e7130723ba11f8a6e14db141f5239d132f8284d4/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/SameThreadTimeoutInvocation.java#L58) a `TimeoutException` when a timeout happens, and the latter [throws](https://github.com/gilbertojrequena/junit5/blob/e91e5dc26b86d0fc0a92f747f0b5dcdc9e5fbec2/junit-jupiter-api/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/AssertTimeout.java#L161) an `AssertionFailedError`. Should we make the exceptions thrown by both of them consistent? 

Is it ok if I create a fix for this bug, or the team wants to handle it internally?

> It seems like [this](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/e7130723ba11f8a6e14db141f5239d132f8284d4/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/SeparateThreadTimeoutInvocation.java#L42) handling is not needed since it is catching the wrong type of exception and also because the `assertTimeoutPreemptively` handles internally the timeout.

> Also, I realized that there are some inconsistencies in the exceptions generated by the `SameThreadTimeoutInvocation#proceed` and the `assertTimeoutPreemptively`. The former [throws](https://github.com/gilbertojrequena/junit5/blob/e7130723ba11f8a6e14db141f5239d132f8284d4/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/SameThreadTimeoutInvocation.java#L58) a `TimeoutException` when a timeout happens, and the latter [throws](https://github.com/gilbertojrequena/junit5/blob/e91e5dc26b86d0fc0a92f747f0b5dcdc9e5fbec2/junit-jupiter-api/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/api/AssertTimeout.java#L161) an `AssertionFailedError`. Should we make the exceptions thrown by both of them consistent?

I think usage of `assertTimeoutPreemptively` in user code should continue to throw an `AssertionFailedError`. The `catch` block in `SeparateThreadTimeoutInvocation` currently makes it so they are consistent, doesn't it? But it's not specific enough since the invocation may throw an `AssertionFailedError` for different reasons (hence this issue).

I think we should create an internal overload of `assertTimeoutPreemptively` (or move it to a separate class) that can be configured with a factory/strategy for creating an exception which is then either `AssertionFailedError` or `TimeoutException`.

> Is it ok if I create a fix for this bug, or the team wants to handle it internally?

Please go ahead. I think we should release 5.9.1 as soon as this issue is fixed.
No, this would only be available internally via a package-private method, if possible.
The problem is that it will not be visible for the `engine`, or am I missing something? ðŸ˜…
No, you're right. In that case, we'll have to resort to making it public and use `@API(status = INTERNAL)`.
